alert.note: Alert for Northeastern Crook; Northern Campbell; Southern Campbell; Western Crook; Weston; Wyoming Black Hills (Wyoming) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS RapidCity (Western South Dakota and Northeastern Wyoming)
info.headline: Winter Storm Watch issued February 20 at 2:54AM MST until February 23 at 5:00AM MST by NWS RapidCity
info.description: ...WIDESPREAD HEAVY SNOW POSSIBLE ALONG WITH VERY COLD TEMPERATURES... .A winter storm will impact the region the middle of this week, likely bringing heavy snow to all of northeast Wyoming and western South Dakota Tuesday night through Wednesday night. Total snow amounts of 6 to 12 inches are possible, with the potential for locally higher amounts over a foot in some areas. Blowing and drifting snow will also be possible in open areas. In addition, an arctic airmass will settle into the region Wednesday, with dangerous wind chills likely through much of Thursday. Listen to NOAA Weather Radio or your local media for the latest updates on this storm. ...WINTER STORM WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM TUESDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH LATE WEDNESDAY NIGHT... * WHAT...Heavy snow possible. Total snow accumulations of 6 to 12 inches possible. Winds could gust as high as 45 mph. * WHERE...Portions of northwestern, southwestern and the Black Hills of South Dakota and northeast and the Black Hills of Wyoming. This includes the Tribal Lands of the Cheyenne River Reservation and the Pine Ridge Reservation. * WHEN...From Tuesday afternoon through late Wednesday night. * IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. Widespread blowing snow could significantly reduce visibility. Gusty winds could bring down tree branches. The dangerously cold wind chills as low as 35 below zero could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.
info.instruction: A Winter Storm Watch means heavy snow, strong winds, freezing precipitation, and cold temperatures are possible. Monitor NOAA weather radio, local radio or television, or the Internet for updates on this potentially dangerous storm. Take time to prepare for severe winter conditions before the storm develops.
